bibl.title: Letter from Edith R. Force to Emilie Lawrence Reed, June 6, 1927

div1.p: Force introduces letters from her students responding to a lesson about Walter Reed and the Yellow Fever Commission.

div1.head: Letter from Edith R. Force to Emilie Lawrence Reed, June 6, 1927
div1.opener:
Edith R. Force
3021 E. 8th Street
Tulsa, Oklahoma
June 6, 1927
Mrs. Walter Reed,
Hotel Burlington,
Vermont Avenue,
Washington, D.C.
div1.p:
This last month, our school Superintendent,
Dr. P.P. Claxton, called our attention to the possiblity of
sending a word of greeting to those who had been in close touch
with the great yellow fever commission.

It is my pleasure to send to you the sincere
altho in many cases very halting, greeting of the boys and girls
in my science classes, from the Woodrow Wilson Junior High School
Tulsa, Oklahoma.

These letters have been their own expression and
reaction to a lesson on yellow fever. They are written by students
of the lowest sections in our school, but nevertheless by ones
who I believe are capable of appreciation of heroic deeds, and of
reaction to good impulses. They have not been corrected in any way.

May you get some slight degree of pleasure from
this expression for you and yours.

Do not feel burdened to reply, even to me, unless
your time and inclination is sufficient for it to be your pleasure.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, Edith R. Force
Science Department,
Wilson Junior High.
